Articles.Content:
Edit: Hi,

Edit: my Kerbal engine comparison chart may be of interest to you. It contains somewhat practical engine test results as well as data gleaned from the KSP game editor (VAB/ SPH) and Wiki. It is sorted by the max mass each engine was able to successfully launch with from sea level, what I designate as "strength". This is sometimes in line with Squad's thrust data, but sometimes not. Altitude figures of a second test at sea level are of each engine using a small tank, which sometimes is in line with iSP, but again, sometimes not. I refer to this as "efficiency". You may also compare Squad's T/WR (and other characteristics) of the engines. All engines are compared (inline, radial; liquid fueled [rocket & jet], solid boosters, monopropellant thrusters, ion; even a Kerbalnaut with EVA pack). Common questions are addressed by the info at the side and keys & comments at the bottom of the chart.

Anyone wishing to sort Squad's data may do so using the interactive page of stock parts at the KSP Wiki. Here is the chart:

For those wishing to download it:

http://kerbalspaceprogram.com/engine-compare-chart/

Details are at the Spaceport and in the chart itself. Thanks!

Edited August 30, 2013 by Dispatcher
SpacePort issues?

Sorry, I just don't understand. You spent a lot of time in game converting the thrust values of stock engines into mass ratings via testing instead of math, and then measured burn rate in terms of some random tank instead of ISP, in such a way that the values in your chart are only useful immediately after launch because every engine except the toroidal aerospike has curves pertaining to velocity and atmospheric density?

You did know that thrust is strength, and ISP is efficiency, right?

Greys, the chart is a result of my wanting to actually experiment with the engines and test them ... sort of like someone wanting to ... build and fly things in KSP. I didn't suffer from the experience; rather enjoyed it actually. I decided to put the data on a chart to share. The tests result in real simulation information. As for thrust (power) and specific impulse, they do not always correlate in sequence (although they tend to do so). The chart is a way of visualizing data in ways that might not be obvious to everyone. For example, 3 radial 24's are quite capable in some applications, but I'd not normally think of using them due to the mere look and sound of them in the game.

Nobody is twisting your arm to use the chart, much less download it. My motivation to make the chart was as a tool for me, and I do use it along with other design considerations in my craft. But I share the chart for anyone that might find it to be useful, or at least entertaining.

Edit: while the mass at lift off may only have meaning at that moment, the column next to it shows max altitude figures, which have some meaning only at the peak of the flight. Also, the test using the small fuel tank yields results which only have meaning at the peak of the flight. It follows that the same view can be had about any data (inc. thrust, iSP or TWR), since those values are maximums and may be made variable by throttle settings, loss of fuel mass and loss of decoupled mass. All of these are static values and it is true that they are best compared in view of changing dynamics (such as graphing the math you mentioned to show a range of possibilities).

Edited August 31, 2013 by Dispatcher
Additional info.

I was searching to see if anyone has done it yet and this is the closest to what I found.

I was thinking of creating a simple in-game mod that will plot selectable metrics for 2 or more parts, e.g. TWR - "Mainsail" vs "Skipper"

Then graph them, could be done fairly easily even by me and of course support any applicable part including all of a user's installed mod parts.

Not aware of anything like it so far, but I just started looking.
